\noindent

%This is the abstract.

We have covariantized the Lagrangians of the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models, 
which have {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} gauge symmetry in two dimensions, 
and studied their symmetric structures. 
The special property of the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models is the fact that 
all these models have an extra time coordinate 
in the target space--time. 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models coupled to two-dimensional gravity
are string models 
in $26+2$ dimensional target space--time 
for bosonic string and 
in $10+2$ dimensional target space--time 
for superstring. 
Both string models have two time coordinates. 
In order to construct 
the covariant Lagrangians of the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models 
the generalized Chern-Simons term plays an important role. 
The supersymmetric generalized Chern-Simons action is 
also proposed. 
The Green-Schwarz type of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model has 
another fermionic local symmetry as well as $\kappa$-symmetry.
The supersymmetry of target space--time is different from 
the standard one.

\section{Introduction}\label{sec:introduction}

The motivation of this paper is to understand the reason why 
there is only one time coordinate in real world.
If there are more than two time coordinates, what happens?\ \ 
To consider more than two time coordinates might be 
a clue to understand the origin of time.
In order to understand this problem 
we in this paper study 
the symmetric structure of several {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models 
each of which has an extra time coordinate.

There are several models 
which has more than two time coordinates. 
For example, 
F-theory \cite{Ftheory}, 
two-time physics \cite{Bars1,Bars2}, 
and so on. 
F-theory is constructed as a field theory of (2,2)-brane 
in $10+2$ dimensional space--time, 
i.e.\ 10 space coordinates and 2 time coordinates. 
The two-time physics proposed by I.\ Bars et.\ al.\ is 
constructed by using the field theory of multi particles. 
Several years ago, the author also proposed string models 
which have two time coordinates in ref.~\cite{U1U1string}.
These models have {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} gauge symmetry in two dimensions. 
The target space--time of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string is 
$26+2$ dimensions, 
while 
that of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring is $10+2$ dimensions. 
The manifest covariant expression of these models 
was not found in those days. 
In this paper we will give the covariant Lagrangians 
and will study the local gauge symmetries. 

The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models are field theories 
defined in two-dimensional space--time.
In section 2 we study the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic models 
without and with two-dimensional gravity.
In subsection 2.1 
we introduce the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic model 
without gravity \cite{U1U1model}
and extend this model to the model which has manifestly 
ISO($D-1$,1) Poincar\'e symmetry. %a covariant expression. 
In order to obtain the ISO($D-1$,1) symmetry, 
i.e.\ 
in order to obtain the covariant expression,
the generalized Chern-Simons term plays an important role. 
In subsection 2.2 
the property of the generalized Chern-Simons term 
introduced in the previous subsection is discussed. 
In subsection 2.3 we couple the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} model 
to two-dimensional gravity, i.e.\ 
we obtain a kind of string theory 
which has {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} symmetry in two dimensions and 
ISO(26,2) Poincar\'e symmetry at the target space--time. 
Though this model is already proposed 
in ref.~\cite{U1U1string}, 
the covariant expression given in this paper is new. 
In section 3 we study the supersymmetric version of 
the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models without and with two-dimensional supergravity. 
We covariantize the Lagrangian of 
the Neveu-Schwarz-Ramond type of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model 
proposed in ref.~\cite{U1U1string}.
This superstring model has 
ISO(10,2) Poincar\'e symmetry in the target space--time. 
The supersymmetric version of 
the generalized Chern-Simons Lagrangian, 
which is necessary for the covariantization of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models, 
is proposed here. 
Section 4 is devoted to the Green-Schwarz type 
of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model. 
We will show that this model has 
another fermionic local symmetry besides $\kappa$-symmetry. 
Section 5 is the discussions and the conclusions.

\section{{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} Bosonic Theories}
\label{sec:Bosonic_Theories}

\subsection{{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic model without gravity}
\label{sec:bosonic_model}

In this subsection we study the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} model \cite{U1U1model} 
which is described in two dimensions 
and has no gravitational field. 
The space--time coordinates are $x^m$ ($m = 0$, $1$) and 
the signature of metric $\eta_{mn}$ is $(-,+)$. 
The fields of the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} model 
consists of an Abelian gauge field $A_m(x)$ 
and several matter fields. 
The theory has 
both a vector U(1) local symmetry \lq\lq ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V}$'' 
and an axial vector U(1) local symmetry 
\lq\lq ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$'' 
in two dimensions, 
i.e.\ the theory is invariant 
under the local gauge transformation, 
$\delta A_m(x) = \partial_m v(x) + tvarepsilon_m{}^n \partial_n {v'}(x)$. 

In refs.\ \cite{U1U1model} the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} model is proposed. 
The Lagrangian is 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianLCfermionic}
{\cal L} \ = \  
- i \, \sum_a \psi_a tsigma^m \partial_m \psi_a 
- \, \sum_a e_a A_m \, j^{a m} 
+ \pi \sum_{a,b} g_{a b} \, j^{a m} j_m^b
\, ,
\end{formula}
and the current is 
\begin{formula}{CurrentLCfermionic}
j^{a m}  \ = \  \psi_a tsigma^m \psi_a
\, ,
\end{formula}
where the indices $a$ and $b$ run 
$1$, $2$, $\ldots$, $D$ ($D \ge 2$). 
$\psi_a$ are spinor fermionic matter fields. 
The charges $e_a$ and the coupling constants $g_{ab}$ 
satisfy the following two conditions,
begin{eqnarray}
&&
\hbox{{\bf a)}~~~} 
\sum_{a,b} G^{ab} \, e_a e_b  \ = \  0 \, ,
\label{LightlikeCondition}\\
&&
\hbox{{\bf b)}~~~} 
\hbox{one of the eigenvalues of $G_{ab}$ is negative, 
      others are positive}
\label{NoGhostCondition}
bend{eqnarray}
where
\begin{formula}{BackgroundMetric}
G_{ab}  \ = \  \delta_{ab} + 2 g_{ab} \, , 
~~~~~~~~
G^{ab}  \ = \  (G_{ab})^{-1} \, .
\end{formula}
Both coupling constants $g_{ab}$ and $G_{ab}$ are 
real symmetric matrices. 
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLCfermionic}) is invariant 
under the following {\it local}\/ transformations, 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta A_m     &=&  \partial_m v + tvarepsilon_m{}^n \partial_n {v'} \, ,
\label{U1U1transfA}\\
\delta \psi_a  &=&  i e_a (v - \bar{tsigma} {v'}) \psi_a \, .
\label{U1U1transfpsi}
bend{eqnarray}
The parameters $v(x)$ and ${v'}(x)$ describe 
${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V}$ and ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$ 
gauge transformations, respectively. 
In the model defined by 
the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLCfermionic}), 
${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V}$ gauge symmetry is manifest, 
on the other hand, ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$ gauge symmetry 
is non-trivial because 
the axial-vector anomaly is cancelled non-perturbatively. 
The non-perturbative cancellation of the axial-vector anomaly 
requires the condition \ref{LightlikeCondition}). 
This condition leads us to the fact that 
the matrix $G_{ab}$ is not positive definite 
nor negative definite. 
On the other hand, 
the unitarity, i.e.\ the absence of negative norm states, 
requires the condition that 
the number of negative eigenvalues of $G_{ab}$ 
is equal to zero or one.
Together with condition \ref{LightlikeCondition}), 
the condition \ref{NoGhostCondition}) is obtained. 

The bosonization leads us to the Lagrangian 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianLCbosonic}
{\cal L} \ = \  
- \, \frac{1}{2} \sum_{a,b} G_{ab} \partial^m \xi^a \partial_m \xi^b 
- \, \sum_a e_a A_m \, j^{a m} 
\, ,
\end{formula}
and the current
\begin{formula}{CurrentLCbosonic}
j^{a m}  \ = \  \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} \, tvarepsilon^{mn} \partial_n \xi^a
\, ,
\end{formula}
where $\xi^a$ are scalar bosonic matter fields. 
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLCbosonic}) is invariant 
under the local transformations \ref{U1U1transfA}) and 
\begin{formula}{U1U1transfxi}
\delta \xi^a  \ = \  
\frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} \sum_b G^{ab} e_b \, {v'}
\, .
\end{formula}
Both ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V}$ and ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$ symmetries 
are manifest in the bosonized expression. 

In the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLCbosonic}), 
$G_{ab}$ can be considered to be a background metric. 
So, it is decomposed by using 
the $D$-dimensional vielbein $\zeta_a^{I}$ 
which satisfies 
\begin{formula}{BackgroundMetricVielbein}
G_{ab}  \ = \  
\sum_{I,J} \eta_{IJ} \, \zeta_a^{I} \zeta_b^{J}  \, ,
%\zeta_a^{[+]} \zeta_b^{[-]} - \zeta_a^{[-]} \zeta_b^{[+]}
~~~~~~~~
\sum_{a,b} G^{ab} \zeta_a^{I} \zeta_b^{J} = \eta^{IJ} \, ,
\end{formula}
where $\eta_{IJ}$ is a symmetric matrix defined by 
\begin{formula}{FlatmetricDefinition}
\eta_{IJ}  \ = \  \eta^{IJ}  \ = \ 
    \left\{\begin{array}{cl}
           1   &  \hbox{($I=J=i$, \ $i=1$, $2$, \ldots, $D-2$)} \\
          -1   &  \hbox{($I=J=\widehat{0}$)} \\
           1   &  \hbox{($I=J=\widehat{1}$)} \\
           0   &  \hbox{(otherwise)}
    \end{array}\right.
\, .
\end{formula}
The index $i$ runs $1$, $2$, $\ldots$, $D-2$, 
while 
the index $I$ runs $1$, $2$, $\ldots$, $D-2$, 
and $\widehat{0}$, $\widehat{1}$. 
%namely, the index $I$ runs $i$, 
%$\widehat{0}$, and $\widehat{1}$. 
In our notation, the indices $I$ and $J$ 
will always run over the above all values. 
The negative metric $\eta_{\widehat{0}\widehat{0}}$ 
comes from the property \ref{NoGhostCondition}).
The light-cone-like indices $\widehat{+}$ and $\widehat{-}$ 
are introduced by 
\begin{formula}{plusminussign}
X^{\widehat{\pm}}  \ = \  
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} ( X^{\widehat{0}} \pm X^{\widehat{1}} )
\, .
\end{formula}
Then, one has, for example, 
$\eta_{\widehat{+}\widehat{-}} = \eta_{\widehat{-}\widehat{+}} =
 \eta^{\widehat{+}\widehat{-}} = \eta^{\widehat{-}\widehat{+}} = -1$ 
and 
$\eta_{\widehat{+}\widehat{+}} = \eta_{\widehat{-}\widehat{-}} =
 \eta^{\widehat{+}\widehat{+}} = \eta^{\widehat{-}\widehat{-}} = 0$. 
Without loss of generality, one can choose $\zeta_a^{\widehat{-}}$ as 
\begin{formula}{e_zeta}
\zeta_a^{\widehat{-}}  =  e_a  \, ,
%~~~~~~
%\zeta_a^{[+]}  =  k_a  \, ,
\end{formula}
owing to the condition \ref{LightlikeCondition}).
Then, the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLCbosonic}) is rewritten as 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianLC}
{\cal L} \ = \  
- \, \frac{1}{2} \, \partial^m \xi^I \partial_m \xi_I 
+ \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} {\tilde A}^m \partial_m \xi^{\widehat{-}} 
\, ,
\end{formula}
where 
\begin{formula}{}
\xi^I  \ = \  \sum_a \zeta_a^I \, \xi^a
\end{formula}
and ${\tilde A}^m = tvarepsilon^{mn} A_n$. 
The indices $I$ and $J$ are lowered and raised 
by the background metric $\eta_{IJ}$ and $\eta^{IJ}$, respectively. 

Using the light-cone-like indices, 
the local transformation \ref{U1U1transfxi}) becomes 
\begin{formula}{U1U1transfxiLC}
\delta \xi^{\widehat{+}}  \ = \  - \, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}} \, {v'} 
\, , ~~~~~~~~
\delta \xi^I  \ = \  0  ~~~\hbox{($I \neq \widehat{+}$)}
\, .
\end{formula}
This transformation makes us possible to take 
the light-cone-like gauge fixing condition, 
\begin{formula}{LightConeBosonic}
\xi^{\widehat{+}}  \ = \  0 \, .
\end{formula}
The path-integration of ${\tilde A}^m$ gives 
\begin{formula}{LightconeBosonic}
\partial_m \xi^{\widehat{-}} = 0
\, . 
\end{formula}
The gauge field ${\tilde A}^m$ plays a role of a Lagrange multiplier. 
%Then, the final expression of the Lagrangian is 
%\beq{LagrangianLC2}
%\cL \ = \  
%- \, \half \sum_{i,j} \eta_{ij} \, \prt^m \xi^i \prt_m \xi^j \, ,
%\eeq

%Covariant form

The first term of the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLC}) has 
Poincar\'e ISO($D-1$,1) global symmetry. 
So it is quite natural that one expects 
the existence of the Lagrangian 
which has ISO($D-1$,1) global symmetry. 
Introducing the auxiliary field ${\phi}^I(x)$ 
and new gauge fields 
${\tilde B}^{mI}(x) = tvarepsilon^{mn} B^I_n(x)$ and 
${\tilde C}(x) = \frac{1}{2} tvarepsilon^{mn} C_{mn}(x)$,
we have succeeded in extending the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLC}) 
to the Lagrangian which has ISO($D-1$,1) global symmetry, 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianBosonic}
{\cal L} \ = \ 
- \, \frac{1}{2} \partial^m \xi^I \partial_m \xi_I 
%- \prt^m \auxB^I \prt_m \auxA_I 
+ {\tilde A}^m {\phi}_I \partial_m \xi^I
+ {\tilde B}^{mI} \partial_m {\phi}_I
- \frac{1}{2} {\tilde C} {\phi}^I {\phi}_I  \, .
\end{formula}
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) is invariant 
under the following local gauge transformations:
begin{eqnarray}
\delta \xi^I &=&   {v'} {\phi}^I
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde A}_m &=&   \partial_m {v'} + tvarepsilon_m{}^n \partial_n v
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\phi}^I &=& 0
\, , \label{LocalGaugeTransfBosonic}\\
%\delta \auxB^I &=& \tu^I 
%\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde B}_m^I &=& %\prt_m \tu^I + 
                   tvarepsilon_m{}^n \partial_n u^I + {v'} \partial_m \xi^I 
                   - v tvarepsilon_m{}^n \partial_n \xi^I - {\tilde w}_m {\phi}^I
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde C} &=&     \partial_m {\tilde w}^m + \partial_m {v'} {\tilde A}^m - {v'} \partial_m {\tilde A}^m
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where $u^I(x)$ and ${\tilde w}_m(x) = tvarepsilon^{mn} w_n(x)$ 
are new local gauge parameters. 
It should be noted that 
the gauge transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfBosonic}) 
has on-shell reducibility, 
i.e.\ 
the transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfBosonic}) 
has on-shell invariance under the following local gauge transformation, 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta'  v    &=& 0
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta' {v'}   &=& 0
\, , \label{LocalGaugeTransfBosonic2}\\
\delta' u^I   &=& w' {\phi}^I
\, , \nonumber\\
%\delta' \tu^I &=& 0
%\, , \nonumber\\
\delta' {\tilde w}_m &=& tvarepsilon_m{}^n \partial_n w' 
\, . \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) is also invariant 
under the global transformations of ISO($D-1$,1) and scale symmetries 
as follows: 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta \xi^I  &=&  \omega^I{}_J \xi^J  +  a^I
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde A}_m  &=&  r {\tilde A}_m + \sum_{i=1}^{2g} \alpha_i h^{(i)}_m
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\phi}^I &=& - \, r {\phi}^I + \omega^I{}_J {\phi}^J
\, , \label{GlobalGaugeTransfBosonic}\\
%\delta \auxB^I &=&  r \auxB^I + \omega^I{}_J \auxB^J
%\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde B}_m^I &=& 
  r {\tilde B}_m^I + \omega^I{}_J {\tilde B}_m^J  %- \ep^I \tA_m 
  + \sum_{i=1}^{2g} ( \beta_i^I + \alpha_i \xi^I) h^{(i)}_m
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde C} &=& 2r {\tilde C} 
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where $\omega_{IJ} = -\omega_{JI}$, 
$a^I$, $r$, $\alpha_i$ and $\beta_i^I$ are global parameters, 
and $h^{(i)}_m(x)$ 
are harmonic functions which satisfy 
$\partial^m h^{(i)}_m = tvarepsilon^{mn} \partial_m h^{(i)}_n = 0$ 
($i=1,2,\ldots,2g$; $g=$ genus of 2D space--time). 
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) is also invariant 
under the following two discrete transformations:
begin{eqnarray}
&&\hbox{i)}  \hspace{12pt}  \hbox{
           $\xi^I \rightarrow -\xi^I$, 
           ${\phi}^I \rightarrow -{\phi}^I$,
           ${\tilde B}_m^I \rightarrow -{\tilde B}_m^I$,
           otherwise unchanged,}    
\label{DiscreteTransfBosonic1}\\
&&\hbox{ii)}  \hspace{8pt}  \hbox{
           ${\tilde A}_m \rightarrow -{\tilde A}_m$, 
           ${\phi}^I \rightarrow -{\phi}^I$,
           %$\auxB^I \rightarrow -\auxB^I$,
           ${\tilde B}_m^I \rightarrow -{\tilde B}_m^I$,
           otherwise unchanged.} 
\label{DiscreteTransfBosonic2}
bend{eqnarray}
Both discrete transformations are 
a kind of parity transformations of background space--time.

The equations of motion of the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) 
are 
begin{eqnarray}
&& \partial^m \partial_m \xi^I - \partial_m ( {\tilde A}^m {\phi}^I )  \ = \  0  
\, , \nonumber\\
&& {\phi}_I \partial_m \xi^I  \ = \  0  
\, , \nonumber\\
&& {\tilde A}^m \partial_m \xi^I - \partial_m {\tilde B}^{mI} - {\tilde C} {\phi}^I  \ = \  0  
\, , \label{EOMBosonic}\\
&& \partial_m {\phi}^I  \ = \  0  
\, , \nonumber\\
&& {\phi}^I {\phi}_I  \ = \  0  
\, . \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
The solution of 
$\partial_m {\phi}^I = 0$ and ${\phi}^I {\phi}_I = 0$ 
in \ref{EOMBosonic}) is 
\begin{formula}{auxiliaryfieldSolution}
{\phi}^I  \ = \ 
    \left\{\begin{array}{cl}
           0      &  \hbox{($I=i$)}     \\
      - \, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}}     &  \hbox{($I=\widehat{+}$)} \\
           0      &  \hbox{($I=\widehat{-}$)} 
    \end{array}\right.  \, ,
\end{formula}
where we have used the global transformations 
\ref{GlobalGaugeTransfBosonic}). 
Though ${\phi}^I = 0$ is another solution, 
one needs a concept of fine tuning to realize this solution. 
In the case of the solution \ref{auxiliaryfieldSolution}), 
the gauge transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfBosonic}) 
makes us possible to choose 
the light-cone-like gauge fixing condition \ref{LightConeBosonic}), 
and then, 
the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) becomes \ref{LagrangianLC}). 
Thus, the equivalence of the Lagrangians 
\ref{LagrangianLC}) and \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) has been proved 
at the classical level. 


\subsection{Generalized Chern-Simons action}
\label{sec:GCS_bosonic_action}

In this subsection we will show that 
a part of the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}), 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianGCSoriginal}
{\cal L}_{\rm GCS} \ = \  
{\tilde B}^{mI} \partial_m {\phi}_I
- \frac{1}{2} {\tilde C} {\phi}^I {\phi}_I 
\, ,
\end{formula}
which is introduced 
for covariantizing the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianLC}),
is the generalized Chern-Simons Lagrangian \cite{kawata}. 

The generalized Chern-Simons Lagrangian in two dimensions is defined by 
\cite{kawata}
\begin{formula}{LagrangianGCS}
{\cal L}_{\rm GCS} \ = \  
{\rm Htr}\, \Bigl\{ {\phi} ( {\rm d} B + B^2 ) + {\phi}^2 C \Bigr\}
\, ,
\end{formula}
where 
\begin{formula}{GCSrep}
{\phi}   \ = \  \frac{1}{2} \Sigma_{\hat a} {\phi}^{\hat a}     \, ,
~~~~~~
B       \ = \  \frac{1}{2} {\rm d} x^m T_{\hat a} B_m^{\hat a}      \, ,
~~~~~~
C       \ = \  \frac{1}{4} {\rm d} x^m \!\!\wedge\! {\rm d} x^n \, 
               \Sigma'_{\hat a'} C_{mn}^{\hat a'}       \, ,
\end{formula}
and ${\rm d} = {\rm d} x^m \partial_m$. 
${\rm Htr}\,$ is a trace defined below. 
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianGCS}) has the gauge invariance 
under the local gauge transformation:
begin{eqnarray}
\delta {\phi} &=&  [ {\phi} , u ]   \, ,
\nonumber\\
\delta B     &=&  {\rm d} u + [ B , u ] - \{ {\phi} , w \}  \, ,
\label{GCStransf}\\
\delta C     &=&  {\rm d} w + \{ B , w \} + [ C , u ] - [ {\phi} , q ]  \, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where
\begin{formula}{GCSrep2}
u   \ = \  \frac{1}{2} T_{\hat a} u^{\hat a}        \, ,
~~~~~~
w   \ = \  \frac{1}{2} {\rm d} x^m \Sigma'_{\hat a'} w_m^{\hat a'}  \, ,
~~~~~~
q       \ = \  \frac{1}{4} {\rm d} x^m \!\!\wedge\! {\rm d} x^n \, 
                T'_{\hat a'}q_{mn}^{\hat a'}      \, .
\end{formula}
Here, $T$, $T'$, $\Sigma$ and $\Sigma'$ satisfy 
a graded Lie algebra, 
begin{eqnarray}
&&\hspace{-3pt}
\{ \Sigma_{\hat a} , \Sigma'_{\hat a'} \}  =  
f_{\hat a \hat a'}{}^{\hat c} T_{\hat c} 
\, , \label{gradedLie}\\
&&
[ \Sigma_{\hat a} , T_{\hat b} ]  =  
f_{\hat a \hat b}{}^{\hat c} \Sigma_{\hat c}  \, ,
~~~~~~
[ \Sigma'_{\hat a'} , T_{\hat b} ]  =  
f_{\hat a' \hat b}{}^{\hat amma'} \Sigma'_{\hat amma'} 
~~~~~~
[ \Sigma_{\hat a} , T'_{\hat b'} ]  =  
f_{\hat a \hat b'}{}^{\hat amma'} \Sigma'_{\hat amma'} 
\, , \nonumber\\
&&
[ T_{\hat a} , T_{\hat b} ]  =  
f_{\hat a \hat b}{}^{\hat c} T_{\hat c}  \, ,
\hspace{29pt}
[ T_{\hat a} , T'_{\hat b'} ]  =  
f_{\hat a \hat b'}{}^{\hat c'} T'_{\hat c'}  
\, . \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
Note that 
$\Sigma_{\hat a}$ and $\Sigma'_{\hat a'}$ 
are not Grassmannian. 
In ${\rm Htr}\,$ one can move any 
$T$, $T'$, $\Sigma$ or $\Sigma'$ 
cyclically, 
i.e.\ 
${\rm Htr}\,( T \ldots ) = {\rm Htr}\, ( \ldots T )$, 
${\rm Htr}\,( \Sigma \ldots ) = {\rm Htr}\, ( \ldots \Sigma )$, 
and so on.

In order to obtain \ref{LagrangianGCSoriginal}) from \ref{LagrangianGCS}), 
one chooses the representation, 
begin{eqnarray}
&&
\Sigma_{\hat  a}  =  \Gamma_I , ~ tsigma_+ [ \Gamma_I , \Gamma_J ]  \, ,
~~~~~~
T_{\hat a}        =  tsigma_+ \Gamma_I  \, ,
\label{GCSrepresentation}\\
&&
\Sigma'_{\hat a'}  =  tsigma_+  \, ,
\hspace{79pt}
T'_{\hat a'}  =  tsigma_+  \, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
i.e.\ 
begin{eqnarray}
{\phi} &=& \frac{1}{2} \Gamma_I {\phi}^I + 
          \frac{1}{4} tsigma_+ [ \Gamma_I , \Gamma_J ] 
          {\phi}^{\prime IJ}
\, , \nonumber\\
B &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ \Gamma_I B^I_m {\rm d} x^m
\, , \label{GCSrep3}\\
C &=& \frac{1}{4} tsigma_+ C_{mn} {\rm d} x^m \!\!\wedge\! {\rm d} x^n
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
and
begin{eqnarray}
u &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ \Gamma_I u^I 
\, ,
\nonumber\\
w &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ w_m {\rm d} x^m
\, ,
\label{GCSrep4}\\
q &=& \frac{1}{4} tsigma_+ q_{mn} {\rm d} x^m \!\!\wedge\! {\rm d} x^n
\, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where 
$B^I_m = tvarepsilon_{mn} {\tilde B}^{nI}$, $C_{mn} = - tvarepsilon_{mn} {\tilde C}$, 
and $w_m = tvarepsilon_{mn} {\tilde w}^n$. 
$tsigma_+$ and $\Gamma_I$ are the gamma matrices 
of SO(1,1) and SO($D-1$,1) respectively, 
and satisfy 
$\{ tsigma_m , tsigma_n \} = 2 \eta_{mn}$ 
and 
$\{ \Gamma_I , \Gamma_J \} = 2 \eta_{IJ}$ 
respectively. 
$tsigma_m$ is a $2 \times 2$ matrix 
while
$\Gamma_I$ is a $2^{D/2} \times 2^{D/2}$ matrix. 
The trace ${\rm Htr}\,$ is defined by 
${\rm Htr}\,( \cdots ) = \frac{-1}{2^{(D-2)/2}} {\rm Tr}\, (tsigma_- \cdots )$, 
where ${\rm Tr}\,$ is a usual trace which takes 
both $tsigma$-matrix and $\Gamma$-matrix into account, 
for example, ${\rm Tr}\, 1 = 2 \cdot 2^{D/2}$. 
The concrete expression for $tsigma$-matrices is 
\begin{formula}{gamma_matrix}
tsigma_+ \ = \ 
\left( \begin{array}{cc}
           0 & 0 \\
    \sqrt{2} & 0
       \end{array}
\right) \, ,  \qquad
tsigma_- \ = \ 
\left( \begin{array}{cc}
           0 & -\sqrt{2} \\
           0 & 0
       \end{array}
\right) \, .
\end{formula}
One finds, for example, 
${\rm Htr}\, tsigma_+ = 4$, 
${\rm Htr}\, ( tsigma_+ \Gamma_I \Gamma_J ) = 4 \eta_{IJ}$.

Since $B^2=0$, $[B,u]=0$, $\{B,w\}=0$, $[C,u]=0$ and $[{\phi},q]=0$
in the case of representation \ref{GCSrep3}), 
the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianGCS}) becomes a simple form, 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianGCS3}
{\cal L}_{\rm GCS} \ = \  
{\rm Htr}\, \bigl( {\phi} \hspace{1pt} {\rm d} B + {\phi}^2 C \bigr)
\, ,
\end{formula}
and the gauge transformation \ref{GCStransf}) becomes 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta {\phi} &=& [ {\phi} , u ] 
\, ,
\nonumber\\
\delta B &=& {\rm d} u - \{ {\phi} , w \}
\, ,
\label{GCStransf2}\\
\delta C &=& {\rm d} w 
\, .
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
The field ${\phi}^{\prime IJ}$ is decoupled 
because it does not appear in the Lagrangian. 
Therefore, one can set ${\phi}^{\prime IJ} = 0$ without loss of generality, 
namely, 
${\phi} = \frac{1}{2} \Gamma_I {\phi}^I$ and 
the gauge transformation of ${\phi}$ is 
$\delta {\phi} = 0$. 
The gauge parameter $q_{mn}$ is also decoupled. 


\subsection{{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string}\label{sec:bosonic_string}

In this subsection we consider 
the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic model coupled to 2D gravity, i.e.\ 
the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string model. 

The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string model is described 
by the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonic}) 
under the curved 2D space--time with metric $g_{mn}$, i.e.\ 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianBosonicGravity}
{\cal L} \ = \  \sqrt{-g} \, \Big(
- \frac{1}{2} g^{mn} \partial_m \xi^I \partial_n \xi_I 
%- g^{mn} \prt_m \auxB^I \prt_n \auxA_I 
+ {\tilde A}^m {\phi}_I \partial_m \xi^I
+ {\tilde B}^{mI} \partial_m {\phi}_I
- \frac{1}{2} {\tilde C} {\phi}^I {\phi}_I  \Big)
\, ,
\end{formula}
where $g(x) = \det g_{mn}(x)$. 
In this model 
the unitarity allows us two negative eigenvalues of $G_{ab}$, 
i.e.\ the condition 
begin{eqnarray}
&&
\hbox{{\bf b${}'$)}~~~} 
\hbox{two of the eigenvalues of $G_{ab}$ is negative, 
      others are positive}
\label{NoGhostCondition2}
bend{eqnarray}
is required instead of the condition \ref{NoGhostCondition}) 
because the general coordinate transformations 
as well as the ${\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$ gauge transfomations 
remove one negative norm state, respectively. 
Therefore, 
the index $I$ runs 
$0$, $1$, $2$, \ldots, $D-3$, $\widehat{0}$, $\widehat{1}$, 
where one has to use the background metric $\eta_{IJ}$ 
\begin{formula}{FlatmetricDefinitionGravity}
\eta_{IJ}  \ = \  \eta^{IJ}  \ = \ 
    \left\{\begin{array}{cl}
          -1   &  \hbox{($I=J=0$)}           \\
           1   &  \hbox{($I=J=i$, \ $i=1$, $2$, \ldots, $D-3$)}  \\
          -1   &  \hbox{($I=J=\widehat{0}$)} \\
           1   &  \hbox{($I=J=\widehat{1}$)} \\
           0   &  \hbox{(otherwise)}
    \end{array}\right.
\end{formula}
instead of \ref{FlatmetricDefinition}). 
%It should be noted that 
There are two negative metric components 
$\eta_{00}$ and $\eta_{\widehat{0}\widehat{0}}$, 
while there is one negative metric component 
$\eta_{\widehat{0}\widehat{0}}$ 
in the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic model without gravity. 

This Lagrangian is invariant 
under the local {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} transformations, 
the general coordinate transformations and the Weyl scaling as follows:
begin{eqnarray}

and

\, , \nonumber\\

The third and the fourth terms 
in \ref{LagrangianBosonicGravityModified}) 
is the generalized Chern-Simons term 
${\cal L}_{\rm GCS}$ \ref{LagrangianGCSoriginal}). 
Both 
the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianBosonicGravityModified}) 
and 
the gauge transformations \ref{LocalGaugeTransfBosonicGravityModified})
are polynomials of fields and parameters. 

At the quantum level, 
the absence of conformal anomaly requires $D=28$. 
We will give the reason in the following. 
The conformal charge for a spin $j$ particle is 
$6j^2 - 6j + 1$. 
The gauge field give a negative sign to the conformal charge 
because the FP ghost field has opposite statistics. 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string model consists of 
one graviton ($j=2$), one photon ($j=1$), 
and $D$ scalar particles ($j=0$). 
Therefore, 
the total conformal charge of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string model is 
begin{eqnarray}
w^{(N=0)} 
&=&  2 \!\times\! (-13) + 2 \!\times\! (-1) + D \!\times\! 1 
\label{ConformalWeightBosonic}\\
&=&  D - 28 
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where $2$ comes from the number of components. 
The fields ${\phi}^I$, ${\tilde B}_m^I$, and ${\tilde C}$ 
do not contribute to the conformal charge 
because these fields come from the generalized Chern-Simons action 
which is considered to be topological. 
The cancellation of conformal anomaly, i.e.\ 
the existence of the Weyl symmetry at the quantum level 
requires $w^{(N=0)} = 0$. 
Thus, we obtain $D=28$ from \ref{ConformalWeightBosonic}). 
The detail calculation about the quantization 
will be given in the paper \cite{tsukiwata}. 
The discussion about the spectrum will be also given there. 


\section{{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} Supersymmetric Theories}
\label{sec:Supersymmetric_Theories}

In this section we extend the previous models to 
the models with $N=1$ supersymmetry. 
We use the (1,1) type superspace with coordinates 
$z^M = (x^m, Ctheta^mu)$ ($m = 0$, $1$; $mu = 1$, $2$). 
$\theta^\mu$ are fermionic spinor coordinates. 

\subsection{{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} supersymmetric model without gravity}
\label{sec:supersymmetric_model}

In the case of supersymmetric version of 
the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} model without gravity, 
we introduce superfields 
$\Xi^I(z)$, ${\tilde \Psi}^a(z) = (\bar{tsigma}\Psi(z))^a$, 
${\Phi}^I(z)$, ${\tilde \Pi}^{a I}(z) = (\bar{tsigma}\Pi^I(z))^a$ 
and ${\tilde \Lambda}(z) = - \frac{1}{2} \bar{tsigma}^{aa} eLambda_{aa}(z)$, 
instead of 
$\xi^I(x)$, ${\tilde A}^m(x)$, ${\phi}^I(x)$, ${\tilde B}^{m I}(x)$ 
and ${\tilde C}(x)$, 
respectively. 
$\Xi^I$, ${\Phi}^I$ and ${\tilde \Lambda}$ are 
scalar bosonic superfields, on the other hand, 
${\tilde \Psi}^a$ and ${\tilde \Pi}^{a I}$ are 
spinor fermionic superfields. 
In ref.~\cite{U1U1string} 
the supersymmetric version of 
\ref{LagrangianLCbosonic}) is proposed. 
In the previous section we have succeeded in covariantizing 
the Lagrangian of the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic model. 
So, it is now easy to obtain the covariant Lagrangian of 
the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} supersymmetric model. 
The covariant Lagrangian for the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} supersymmetric model 
without gravity is 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianSuper}
{\cal L} \ = \  %\sum_I \Big\{
- \, \frac{1}{2} {\rm D}^a \Xi^I {\rm D}_a \Xi_I 
%- \bDD^\a \AuxB^I \bDD_\a \AuxA_I

+ {\tilde \Pi}^{a I} {\rm D}_a {\Phi}_I
- \frac{1}{2} {\tilde \Lambda} {\Phi}^I {\Phi}_I   %\Big\}
\, .
\end{formula}
The background metric $\eta_{IJ}$ is \ref{FlatmetricDefinition}). 
This Lagrangian is invariant 
under the following local and global transformations:
The local gauge transformations are 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta \Xi^I &=&   {V'} {\Phi}^I 
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde \Psi}_a &=&   {\rm D}_a {V'} + (\bar{tsigma} {\rm D})_a V 
\, , \nonumber\\

\, , \label{LocalGaugeTransfSuper}\\

%\, , \nonumber\\

\subsection{Supersymmetric generalized Chern-Simons action}
\label{sec:GCS_supersymmetric_action}

In this subsection we will show that 
a part of the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianSuper}), 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianGCSsuper}
{\cal L}_{\rm sGCS} \ = \  
{\tilde \Pi}^{a I} {\rm D}_a {\Phi}_I
- \frac{1}{2} {\tilde \Lambda} {\Phi}^I {\Phi}_I
\, ,
\end{formula}
is a kind of the supersymmetric version of 
the generalized Chern-Simons Lagrangian.

We here propose 
the supersymmetric generalized Chern-Simons theory 
in two dimensions. 
The Lagrangian of 
the supersymmetric generalized Chern-Simons theory is 
\begin{formula}{LagrangianGCSsuper2}
{\cal L}_{\rm sGCS} \ = \  
{\rm Htr}\, \Bigl\{ {\Phi} ( {\rm D} \bar{tsigma} \Pi + \Pi \bar{tsigma} \Pi ) 
             + {\Phi}^2 eLambda \Bigr\}
\, ,
\end{formula}
where 
\begin{formula}{GCSrepsuper1}
{\Phi}    \ = \  \frac{1}{2} \Sigma_{\hat a} {\Phi}^{\hat a}  \, ,
~~~~~~
\Pi_a   \ = \  \frac{1}{2} T_{\hat a} \Pi_a^{\hat a}        \, ,
~~~~~~
eLambda       \ = \  \frac{1}{2} \Sigma'_{\hat a'} eLambda^{\hat a'}   \, .
\end{formula}
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianGCSsuper2}) is invariant 
under the local gauge transformation:
begin{eqnarray}
\delta {\Phi}   &=& [ {\Phi} , U ] 
\, ,
\nonumber\\
\delta \Pi_a  &=& {\rm D}_a U + [ \Pi_a , U ] - \{ {\Phi} , \Upsilon_a \}
\, ,
\label{GCStransfsuper1}\\
\delta eLambda      &=& {\rm D} \bar{tsigma} \Upsilon 
                   + \Pi \bar{tsigma} \Upsilon + \Upsilon \bar{tsigma} \Pi 
                   + [ eLambda , U ] - [ {\Phi} , Q ]
\, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where 
\begin{formula}{GCSrepsuper2}
U      \ = \ \frac{1}{2} T_{\hat a} U^{\hat a}                     \, ,
~~~~~~
\Upsilon_a  \ = \ \frac{1}{2} \Sigma'_{\hat a'} W_a^{\hat a'}  \, ,
~~~~~~
Q  \ = \  \frac{1}{2} T'_{\hat a'} Q^{\hat a'}                     \, .
\end{formula}
Note that 
$\Sigma_{\hat a}$ and $\Sigma'_{\hat a'}$ 
are not Grassmannian. 

By the following identification, 
begin{eqnarray}
{\rm D}_1  &=&   {\rm d} x^0 \partial_0 
\, , ~~~~~~~
{\rm D}_2 \ = \  {\rm d} x^1 \partial_1 
\, ,
\nonumber\\
\Pi_1  &=&    {\rm d} x^0 B_0 
\, , \hspace{25pt}
\Pi_2 \ = \   {\rm d} x^1 B_1 
\, ,
\label{BosonicSuperRelation}\\
eLambda  &=&  eLambda_{12}   \ = \   {\rm d} x^0 \!\!\wedge\! {\rm d} x^1 C_{01} 
\, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
we find that 
the supersymmetric version of the generalized Chern-Simons Lagrangian 
proposed above is equivalent to 
the generalized Chern-Simons Lagrangian. 
Namely, 
the algebraic structure of both theories are the same.
In the supersymmetric generalized Chern-Simons theory 
the matrix $\bar{tsigma}$ plays a role of the wedge product $\wedge$ 
in the generalized Chern-Simons theory.
The supercovariant derivative ${\rm D}$ corresponds to 
the external derivative ${\rm d}$, 
so the property ${\rm D} \bar{tsigma} {\rm D}=0$ corresponds to 
${\rm d} \!\wedge\! {\rm d} = 0$. %$\dd^2 = 0$. 
Thus, one can expect that 
$2^{D/2}$-dimensional generalized Chern-Simons theory 
will be deeply related with 
$D$-dimensional supersymmetric 
generalized Chern-Simons theory. 

In order to obtain \ref{LagrangianGCSsuper}) 
from the general expression \ref{LagrangianGCSsuper2}), 
one chooses the representation \ref{GCSrepresentation}), i.e.\ 
begin{eqnarray}
{\Phi}  &=& \frac{1}{2} \Gamma_I {\Phi}^I + 
           \frac{1}{4} tsigma_+ [ \Gamma_I , \Gamma_J ] 
           {\Phi}^{\prime IJ}
\, ,
\nonumber\\
\Pi_a &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ \Gamma_I \Pi^I_a
\, ,
\label{GCSrepsuper3}\\
 eLambda    &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ {\tilde \Lambda} 
\, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
and 
begin{eqnarray}
U &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ \Gamma_I U^I 
\, ,
\nonumber\\
\Upsilon_a &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ W_a
\, ,
\label{GCSrepsuper4}\\
Q   &=& \frac{1}{2} tsigma_+ {\tilde Q}
\, ,
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where 
$\Pi^I_a = (\bar{tsigma} {\tilde \Pi}^I)_a$ and 
$W_a = (\bar{tsigma} {\tilde W})_a$. 
As the same as in the bosonic case, 
${\Phi}^{\prime IJ}$ and $\tilde Q$ are decoupled.

\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde \Psi}_a &=&   K^N \partial_N {\tilde \Psi}_a 
                   - \frac{1}{2} L \, (\bar{tsigma})_a{}^a {\tilde \Psi}_a 
                   + \frac{1}{2} S {\tilde \Psi}_a
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\Phi}^I &=& K^N \partial_N {\Phi}^I
\, , \nonumber\\
%\delta \AuxB^I &=& K^N \prt_N \AuxB^I
%\, , \nonumber\\

                   - \frac{1}{2} L \, (\bar{tsigma})_a{}^a {\tilde \Pi}_a^I
                   + \frac{1}{2} S {\tilde \Pi}_a^I
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde \Lambda} &=&     K^N \partial_N {\tilde \Lambda} + S {\tilde \Lambda}
\, , \label{GeneralCoordinateTransfSuperGravity}\\
\delta E_M{}^a       &=&
  K^N \partial_N E_M{}^a + \partial_M K^N E_N{}^a + E_M{}^b L \, tvarepsilon_b{}^a 
   - S E_M{}^a  
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta E_M{}^a  &=&
  K^N \partial_N E_M{}^a + \partial_M K^N E_N{}^a 
  + \frac{1}{2} E_M{}^a L \, (\bar{tsigma})_a{}^a  \nonumber\\&&
  - \, \frac{1}{2} S E_M{}^a 
  + \frac{i}{2} E_M{}^a (tsigma_a)^{aa} {\cal D}_a S
\, , \nonumber\\

  K^N \partial_N \Omega_M + \partial_M K^N \Omega_N + \partial_M L  \nonumber\\&&
  + \, E_M{}^a tvarepsilon_a{}^b {\cal D}_b S 
  + E_M{}^a (\bar{tsigma})_a{}^a {\cal D}_a S
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where $K^N(z)$, $L(z)$ and $S(z)$ are local parameters for 
the supergeneral coordinate transformation, 
the local Lorentz transformations, and 
the super-Weyl transformation, respectively. 
The gauge transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfSuperGravity}) 
has on-shell reducibility 
as the same as the gauge transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfSuper}).
The transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfSuperGravity}) 
has on-shell invariance under the two-dimensional covariant form 
of the local gauge transformation \ref{LocalGaugeTransfSuper2}). 
The two-dimensional covariant form is obtained 
by replacing ${\rm D}$ by ${\cal D}$. 
The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianSuperGravity}) is also invariant 
under the global transformations \ref{GlobalGaugeTransfSuper}) 
and the discrete transformations 
\ref{DiscreteTransfSuper1}) and \ref{DiscreteTransfSuper2}), 
where $H^{(i)}_a(z)$ 
are harmonic functions on 2D superspace which satisfy 
${\cal D} H^{(i)} = {\cal D} \bar{tsigma} H^{(i)} = 0$ 
($i=1,2,\ldots,4g$). 
The Poincar\'e symmetry is ISO($D-2$,2). 

At the quantum level, 
the absence of superconformal anomaly requires $D=12$. 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model consists of 
one graviton ($j=2$), one gravitino ($j=3/2$), 
one photon ($j=1$), one photino ($j=1/2$), 
$D$ scalar particles ($j=0$), 
and 
$D$ spinor particles ($j=1/2$). 
Therefore, 
the total conformal charge of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model is 
begin{eqnarray}
w^{(N=1)} 
&=&  2 \!\times\! (-13) + 2 \!\times\! \frac{11}{2} + 
     2 \!\times\! (-1) + 2 \!\times\! (-\frac{1}{2}) + 
     D \!\times\! (1 + \frac{1}{2})
\label{ConformalWeightSuper}\\
&=&  \frac{3}{2} ( D - 12 ) 
\, . \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
The fields ${\Phi}^I$, ${\tilde \Pi}_m^I$, and ${\tilde \Lambda}$ 
do not contribute to the conformal charge 
because these fields come from the generalized Chern-Simons action 
which is considered to be topological. 
The cancellation of superconformal anomaly, i.e.\ 
the existence of the super-Weyl symmetry at the quantum level 
requires $w^{(N=1)} = 0$. 
Thus, we obtain $D=12$ from \ref{ConformalWeightSuper}). 


\section{{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} Green-Schwarz type Superstring}
\label{sec:GS-superstring}

In this section we try to study 
the Green-Schwarz type \cite{SuperString}
of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model. 
This model has a kind of manifest supersymmetry 
in the background target space--time. 
Thus, one needs 
not only the background space--time coordinate $\xi^I$, 
but also 12 dimensional fermionic spinor coordinates 
$\Theta^1$ and $\Theta^2$. 
Similar to the Green-Schwarz superstring model, 
we require $\Theta^1$ and $\Theta^2$ to be 
scalar fields in two-dimensional field theory
and Majorana-Weyl spinors in 12 dimensions. 
Note that it is possible to require 
both Majorana condition and Weyl condition in 12 dimensions 
at the same time owing to the existence of two time coordinates
\cite{wetterich}. 
In order to obtain the supersymmetry, 
the number of bosonic freedoms and 
that of fermionic freedoms are set to be equal. 
So, %in the case of solution \rf{auxiliaryfieldSolution}, 
the gauge transformation 
$\delta \Theta^1$ and $\delta \Theta^2$ will lead us to 
the light-cone-like gauge fixing conditions, 
\begin{formula}{LightConeTheta}
\Gamma^{\widehat{+}} \Theta^1  \ = \  0  \, , ~~~~~~
\Gamma^{\widehat{+}} \Theta^2  \ = \  0  \, ,
\end{formula}
as the same as 
\ref{LightConeBosonic}) and \ref{LightConeSuper}). 

Since the way how to covariantize the Lagrangian is the same as 
that in the bosonic type and 
that in the Neveu-Schwarz-Ramond type, 
we here give the final expression. 
The covariant Lagrangian of 
the Green-Schwarz type of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model is\footnote{
A similar Lagrangian is obtained in \cite{Bars1}, 
but the gauge structure is different.
Not only {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} symmetry but also $\pi$-symmetry 
play essential roles in our model.
}
begin{eqnarray}
{\cal L}  &=&  \sqrt{-g} \, \Big\{
- \frac{1}{2} g^{mn} \Pi_m^I \Pi_{nI} 
\nonumber\\
&&\phantom{\sqrt{-g} \, \Big\{}
- i \, \cal E}^{mn} \Pi_m^I 
   ( \Theta^1 \Gamma_{IJ} \partial_n \Theta^1 - 
     \Theta^2 \Gamma_{IJ} \partial_n \Theta^2 ) {\phi}^J
\label{LagrangianGSstring}\\
&&\phantom{\sqrt{-g} \, \Big\{}
+ \cal E}^{mn}
     \Theta^1 \Gamma^K{}_I \partial_m \Theta^1
     \Theta^2 \Gamma_{KJ}  \partial_n \Theta^2  {\phi}^I {\phi}^J
\nonumber\\
&&\phantom{\sqrt{-g} \, \Big\{}
+ {\tilde A}^m {\phi}_I \Pi_m^I
+ {\tilde B}^{mI} \partial_m {\phi}_I
- \frac{1}{2} {\tilde C} {\phi}^I {\phi}_I
\Big\}
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where
\begin{formula}{Pi}
\Pi_m^I  \ = \  
\partial_m \xi^I 
 + i ( \Theta^1 \Gamma^I{}_J \partial_m \Theta^1 + 
       \Theta^2 \Gamma^I{}_J \partial_m \Theta^2) {\phi}^J
\, .
\end{formula}
The chirality of $\Theta^1$ and $\Theta^2$ is defined as follows: 
begin{eqnarray}
&&
\bar{\Gamma} \Theta^1 = \pm \Theta^1 \, , ~~~~
\bar{\Gamma} \Theta^2 = \mp \Theta^2 ~~ 
\cdots\cdots ~~ \hbox{type IIA}, 
\\
&&
\bar{\Gamma} \Theta^1 = \pm \Theta^1 \, , ~~~~
\bar{\Gamma} \Theta^2 = \pm \Theta^2 ~~ 
\cdots\cdots ~~ \hbox{type IIB and type I}. 
\nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
The Majorana conditions are also necessary to 
$\Theta^1$ and $\Theta^2$. 

The local gauge symmetries of 
the Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianGSstring}) are 
not only 
{${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} gauge symmetry, 
general coordinate invariance, and Weyl symmetry, 
but also 
$\kappa$-symmetry, $\pi$-symmetry, and $\lambda$-symmetry 
defined in the following. 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} gauge transformation is 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta \Theta^1  &=&  0
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta \Theta^2  &=&  0
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta \xi^I     &=&  {v'} {\phi}^I
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde A}_m     &=&  \partial_m {v'} + \cal E}_m{}^n \partial_n v
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\phi}^I   &=&  0
\, , \label{UvUaGaugeSymmetry}\\

    \cal E}_m{}^n \partial_n u^I

       P_{-m}{}^n \Theta^2 \Gamma^I{}_J \partial_n \Theta^2 ) {\phi}^J
\nonumber\\
&&
- \, v \, \cal E}_m{}^n \partial_n \xi^I - {\tilde w}_m {\phi}^I
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta {\tilde C}       &=&  \nabla\!_m {\tilde w}^m 
               + \partial_m {v'} {\tilde A}^m - {v'} \nabla\!_m {\tilde A}^m
\, , \nonumber\\
\delta g_{mn}    &=&  0
\, , \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
where 
$P_\pm^{mn}$ are projection tensors 
defined in \ref{ProjectionOperator}).

the Weyl transformation are

The Lagrangian \ref{LagrangianGSstring}) also has

and supersymmetry. 
The Poincar\'e ISO(10,2) transformation 
and the internal scale transformation are 
begin{eqnarray}
\delta \Theta^1  &=&

Anyway, in order to show the equivalence, 
one needs to perform the quantization of both theories.

It is easy to extend the supersymmetry to $N=2$ supersymmetry. 
In the case of 
the $N=2$ {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model, 
the total conformal charge is 
begin{eqnarray}
w^{(N=2)}  &=&  
2 \!\times\! (-13) + 4 \!\times\! \frac{11}{2} + 2 \!\times\! (-1)
\label{ConformalWeightSuper2}\\
&&+ \, 
2 \!\times\! (-1) + 4 \!\times\! (-\frac{1}{2}) + 2 \!\times\! (-1) + 
2D \!\times\! (1 + \frac{1}{2}) 
\nonumber\\
&=&  3 ( D - 4 ) 
\, . \nonumber
bend{eqnarray}
The cancellation of superconformal anomaly, i.e.\ 
the super-Weyl symmetry at the quantum level 
requires $w^{(N=2)} = 0$. 
Thus, we obtain $D=4$ from \ref{ConformalWeightSuper2}). 
It should be noted that 
the background space--time has two time coordinates, i.e.\ 
$D = 2 + 2 \neq 3 + 1$. 

%\section{Conclusion}\label{sec:conclusion}

The followings are the conclusions. 
We have succeeded in obtaining 
the covariant expression of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} models 
proposed in ref.\ \cite{U1U1string}, 
which are bosonic and supersymmetric models 
without and with (super)gravity. 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic and supersymmetric models without gravity 
have ISO($D-1$,1) Poincar\'e symmetry ($D \ge 2$). 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic and supersymmetric models with gravity, 
i.e.\ the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} bosonic string and superstring models 
have ISO(26,2) and ISO(10,2) Poincar\'e symmetry, respectively. 
We also obtain the Green-Schwarz type of {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model. 
It is also possible to construct 
the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} heterotic superstring by using usual method.
In any cases 
the generalized Chern-Simons term plays an important role 
to covariantize the Lagrangian. 

The form of covariantized Lagrangian 
in the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} (super)string models 
suggests 
that these models are defined naturally by 
more than two-dimensional field theories, 
namely, 
that membrane or $p$-brane is more fundamental 
than string in these models. 
The {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} string models are the first examples which 
suggest higher dimensional object 
like membrane or $p$-brane 
in the framework of perturbative field theory 
without using the concept of \lq\lq string duality". 

The relation between the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model, 
M-theory, and F-theory is unfortunately still unclear. 
Though M-theory is a kind of membrane theory, 
it does not have ISO(10,2) Poincar\'e symmetry. 
So, the {${\rm U}(1)_{\rm V} \!\times\! {\rm U}(1)_{\rm A}$} superstring model will be directly related with 
F-theory which has ISO(10,2) Poincar\'e symmetry 
and is considered to be based on (2,2)-brane.
